Subject: Re: [neat] Thesis on characteristics of HyperNEAT, plus a Java
 implementation of HyperNEAT [1 Attachment]
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=467342474; y=6DdJUt2PE9vwPuQXv9mRFxhl1ZzL1bgbrg-2DJa3CC5KVjPhHG0s
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello Oliver-

I recently finished reading your thesis. I commend you on the excellent
work. It is very well written, thorough, and interesting. Are you planning
on submitting it for publication? I think it would be well-received.

Out of curiosity, did you try your pattern recognition tasks (e.g., the ones
in fig. 8) without scaling? Do you know whether evolving at the highest
resolution is easier/harder for HyperNEAT than evolving at lower resolutions
and scaling up? I am talking about performance per generation, not
performance per amount of cpu/clock time.

On pg. 58 you mention that nodes could be represented in 3D instead of 2D.
You may already be aware of this, but I actually tried that with the
Quadruped Gait evolution problem. We found that 3D did not help vs. 2D
(although both 3D and 2D beat 1D).

That work is described in this paper:

Clune J, Pennock RT, and Ofria C (2009). The sensitivity of HyperNEAT to
different geometric representations of a problem. Proceedings of the Genetic
and Evolutionary Computation Conference (GECCO). 675-682.

Congrats again on the excellent work, and thanks for sending it to the list.

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Computational Synthesis Laboratory
Cornell University
jeffclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune

**Call for papers! Generative and Developmental Systems Track, GECCO 2011
(Dublin). Deadline Jan. 26th.**


> From: Oliver Coleman <oliver@...>
> Organization: e-geek
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sat, 04 Dec 2010 09:44:14 +1100
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Thesis on characteristics of HyperNEAT, plus a Java
> implementation of HyperNEAT [1 Attachment]
> 
> Hi all,
> 
> I've recently completed a thesis on some of the properties and
> characteristics of HyperNEAT. The abstract is below; the thesis is
> attached. As part of this work I created a Java implementation of
> HyperNEAT, it is currently available on the NEAT group page in the files
> section and should soon be up on the HyperNEAT User's Page (when Ken
> gets around to it).
> 
> Cheers,
> Oliver
> 
> Abstract:
> 
> In this study a recently developed neuroevolution method, HyperNEAT, is
> applied to new tasks in order to learn more about its characteristics in
> general and for the tasks specifically. The tasks required directly
> processing raw image data, including some from a robot-mounted camera,
> requiring the neural networks to directly process hundreds or thousands
> of inputs. The tasks included object recognition and robot navigation.
> The complexity and properties of the tasks, as well as the neural
> network substrate topologies, were varied and the performance and
> characteristics of the evolutionary process and solutions generated were
> analysed. Positive results were achieved for non-trivial tasks, and some
> important characteristics of HyperNEAT not previously reported were
> discovered: a bias towards generating weight patterns aligned with the
> topographical arrangement of neurons within the layers of the substrate
> network; the impact on performance of the number of dimensions in the
> topographical arrangement of neurons in hidden layers; the ability to
> evolve solutions more quickly with larger substrate networks; and a
> possible difficulty co-evolving weight patterns for substrate networks
> containing more than one hidden layer. New directions for further
> research and possible enhancements to HyperNEAT are proposed based on
> these findings.
> 
> 
> --
